awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Spatial Ensemble Structure in Visual Working Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
Visual working memory allows people to hold visual information in mind for a brief period of time, making it available for other cognitive tasks. Research investigating this memory system has found that people are capable of storing only a few of the many objects that we see in most visual scenes. However, memory does not hold only objects - we also remember large-scale spatial relationships ("spatial ensembles") that provide us with information about where objects are located and what they are like on average. The project will introduce new research methods designed to gather information about visual working memory for ensembles as well as individual objects. Visual working memory is critical for everyday functioning and closely related to fluid intelligence and academic achievement. Disruptions of working memory are common in clinical disorders like AHDH and schizophrenia. Thus, understanding how the human visual system stores information about objects and ensembles in working memory is critical for understanding important differences between individuals as well as improving our understanding of visual skills, such as those involved in driving and other complex tasks that require remembering and monitoring multiple objects and their respective locations. Understanding how memories for objects and ensembles interact can also inform the design of artificial vision systems. The research plan includes a significant outreach component, featuring both the recruitment and training of first-generation college students from underrepresented groups and the development of tools to allow scientists to conduct online experiments and teach them how to do so.

The research aims to broadly understand how the working memory system makes use of ensemble structure. First, the research investigates whether memory for objects is dissociable from memory for ensemble structure (e.g., whether object memory can be preserved when ensemble memory is impaired). Second, the research asks what broader cognitive capacities might be related to working memory for ensembles. In particular, it focuses on scene recognition, with the hypothesis that rapid recognition of visual scenes may be related to ensemble representations in working memory. To investigate these issues, a set of rigorous experimental and computational techniques will be used, including a novel paradigm based on 3d-viewpoint manipulations, as well as probabilistic/Bayesian models of visual memory that can be used to dissociate object vs. ensemble contributions to performance on working memory tasks. These techniques will allow for quantitative tests of the way in which ensembles and individual objects interact in visual working memory and the way in which they relate to broader cognitive abilities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Visual working memory allows people to temporarily hold visual information in mind, making it available for other cognitive tasks. Research investigating this memory system reveals that people are capable of accurately storing information about only a few of the objects present in most visual scenes. However, working memory does not store only individual objects ? we also remember more general spatial structures (?spatial ensembles?), providing us with information about where objects are located and what they are like on average. This project introduced new research methods designed to obtain information about visual working memory for ensemble structure and the effects of ensemble structure on memory for individual objects. It then applied these methods to understanding how people represent visual scenes, as well as controlled visual displays and artificial displays like data visualizations. 

Understanding how we store such information is important because visual working memory is critical for everyday functioning and is closely related to fluid intelligence and academic achievement. Disruptions of working memory are common in clinical disorders like ADHD and schizophrenia. Therefore, understanding how the human visual system stores information about objects and ensembles in working memory is useful for understanding individual differences and improving our understanding of how visual processing affects visual skills like reading data graphs.  

This research aimed to gain a broad understanding of how the working memory system uses ensemble structure. It revealed that rapid recognition of visual scenes is linked to ensemble representations in working memory. Moreover, it revealed that the representation of individual objects in working memory is reliably distorted by ensemble information even when people?s task is only to remember the individual objects. The research investigated the role of 3d structure and 2d cues to 3d structure in visual working memory, and how they related to ensemble representations.  The research also led to the development of a new computational model of visual working memory, and investigated how to best measure visual working memory capacity. 

The research plan also had a significant outreach component, involving the recruitment and training of first-generation college students from underrepresented groups. The grant supported paying such students to participate in a summer program aimed at providing research opportunities. The grant also funded the development of tools to allow scientists to conduct online experiments and teach them how to do so.


Last Modified: 04/24/2023
Modified by: Timothy Brady
